titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Franklin M. Fisher Papers, 1958-2012 RL.11059
titlestmt.author: Meghan Lyon

publicationstmt.publisher: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-03-05 16:16:25 -0500.

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.unittitle: Franklin M. Fisher papers
did.abstract: Franklin Marvin Fisher (1934-2019) was an American economist and professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology since 1960 until he became professor emeritus in 2004. The collection includes materials documenting Fisher's professional life as an economist and professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. It contains Fisher's professional correspondence, including letters of recommendation and reader reports; a portion of this series is restricted during Fisher's lifetime. The collection also contains writings by Fisher, including including drafts and typescripts of articles and writings on corporate monopolies, natural resources and commodities, aggregate production, equilibrium, and econometrics. There is also a significant body of work from Fisher's collaboration with Karl Shell on their book, Economic Analysis of Price Production Indexes. Another large portion of the collection documents Fisher's consulting work, especially his role as an expert witness on a variety of monopoly and antitrust cases, including US vs. IBM, Eastman Kodak vs. Polaroid, and US vs. Microsoft. Also represented in the papers is Fisher's role in the Harvard Middle East Water Project, the Peace Now Project, and other projects seeking to bring peace through water allocation. Finally, the papers include details about Fisher's various professional engagements and membership in various associations, as well as his teaching files, lecture notes, and assorted materials related to his appointment at MIT.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Collection is arranged into series: Correspondence; Consulting Work, Projects, and Service; Engagements; Lectures and Teaching; and Writings.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Franklin Marvin Fisher (1934-2019) was an economist and professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. He specialized in industrial organization, microeconomics, and econometrics, and served as an expert witness in numerous antitrust legal cases. He was also involved in projects involving conflict resolution and water management.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Collection is restricted. Fisher's referee reports and letters of recommendation are closed to research and require written permission from the donor for access. The rest of the collection is open for research.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Franklin M. Fisher Papers were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a gift from Franklin M. Fisher in 2005 and 2012. Acc. 2019-0170 was received as a gift from Ellen Fisher in 2019.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Franklin M. Fisher Papers, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Sonia Manseri, Sandra Niethardt, and Meghan Lyon, October 2015. Updated by Meghan Lyon in March 2021.
Accessions described in this collection guide: 2005-0064, 2012-0257, 2019-0170

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The Franklin M. Fisher Papers document the research, teaching, writings, and professional activities of noted MIT economist Franklin Fisher. The collection reflects Fisher's wide-ranging interests and expertise, including his collaboration on water management and conflict resolution issues in the Middle East; his work as a legal expert on anti-trust lawsuits for assorted corporations and the U.S. Dept. of Justice; his service as a professor and mentor to numerous economics students, largely between the 1970s and 1990s; and his correspondence with leading economists such as Robert Clower, Frank Hahn, Peter Diamond, and Lawrence Klein. His materials have been arranged into series: Writings, Lectures and Teaching, Engagements, Consulting Work, and Correspondence.

did.unittitle: Correspondence

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The Referee Reports and Recommendations are closed to use. Written permission is required from the donor to access these materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Fisher's Correspondence Series consists largely of professional and academic correspondence relating to his research and consulting work. The General Correspondence subseries documents his exchanges with assorted economists, publishers, law firms, and professional groups. Also included in this subseries is Fisher's correspondence with the Econometric Society. Also held in the Correspondence Series is Fisher's Referee Reports and his Recommendations, which largely relate to his role as a professor and mentor to students at MIT. Be advised that access to these subseries is restricted and requires written permission from Fisher.

Lectures and Teaching

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Lectures and Teaching Series contains assorted materials from Fisher's economics classes at MIT, including exams, problem sets, and notes from Economic Principles, Microeconomic Theory, and others. The series also contains some lecture notes from Fisher's 1984 trip to China and other miscellaneous events. Additional materials related to public lectures can be found in the Writings and Engagements series.

Writings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Fisher's Writings Series has been divided into subseries: Articles and Essays; Miscellaneous Notes and Reviews; Books (which includes his Collected Works); and Work with Karl Shell. The Articles and Essays subseries documents Fisher's wide-ranging professional interests, including writings on corporate monopolies, natural resources and commodities, aggregate production, equilibrium, and econometrics. Some of these articles overlap with the Karl Shell subseries. The majority of the Karl Shell subseries relates to Fisher and Shell's collaboration on their book, Economic Analysis of Price Production Indexes, including correspondence, drafts, and research. Materials from other books by Fisher are represented in the Books subseries, but researchers should be advised that not every book written by Fisher is represented in the collection, and some titles have only book reviews or supplemental materials. The Books subseries also includes drafts and preparatory material from the publication of Fisher's Collected Works. Finally, Fisher's Miscellaneous Notes subseries includes some unidentified notes, as well as assorted book reviews and other writings by Fisher commenting on other economics research.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The majority of Fisher's consulting work relates to his role as a legal expert for a variety of monopoly and anti-trust cases, both as an independent scholar and as a partner in Charles River Associates. Some of the cases represented here had widespread impact on US antitrust law, including US vs. IBM, Eastman Kodak vs. Polaroid, and US vs. Microsoft. The Consulting Work Series also includes materials from Fisher's involvement in assorted projects, in particular Harvard University's Middle East Water Project. Other subseries include Fisher's professional service, his workshops, and his reports. There may be additional materials related to these subseries in the Correspondence, Writings, and Engagements series.

did.unittitle: Expert Witness Files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Fisher's Expert Witness Files include copies of his depositions, court transcripts, supplemental research files, and other materials he acquired in his role as expert witness in a number of legal cases. These materials occasionally include notations that they are confidential; Fisher has attested that they are open for research.

Engagements

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Engagements series contains event files and correspondence documenting Fisher's invitations and participation in various professional events, largely conferences and economics summits. A portion of this series is grouped in loose chronological order; other portions are filed chronologically by event.
